items.title: Cowry Shells as Primitive Money
notes: Cowries used as legal tender and medium of exchange.
Some shells filled with lead to increase exchange value; lead is soft/dense/cheap and melts at ~327°C.
Examples shown include shells ~8.42 g and ~11.71 g.

items.title: Metal Cowri (Start of ‘Metallic Coinage’)
notes: ‘Metal Cowri’ first cast in lead, later in bronze.
Value depended on weight of the cowries.

items.title: Rani Cowri (Highest Value Segment)
notes: Lead metal in coin shape fixed inside cowry; shown example weight ~23.20 g.

items.title: Futi (Broken) Cowries
notes: Broken (‘Futi’) cowries stated to have no value in trade.

items.title: 1st Stage of Metallic Money — Lead Globs/Pieces
notes: Defines money as a medium of exchange; lists many world examples (whale teeth, stones, shells, grain, cattle, metals, tools).
Lead ‘globs/pieces’ used as primitive money.

items.title: 2nd Stage of Metallic Money — Lead Beads Woven into Belt
notes: Lead beads woven into a belt used for ornamentation and in emergency as money.

items.title: Ujjaini Region — Terracotta Coins & ‘Buddha Topi’
notes: Board segment shows terracotta coin forms attributed to Ujjaini region; also mentions ‘Buddha Topi’ piece.

items.title: Saurashtra Region — Beads Money
notes: Different shapes used as money (selection shown in the middle strip of the board).

items.title: Kaushambi (Pali) Region — Metal & Stone Pieces
notes: Lower strip shows metal and stone pieces classified under Kaushambi (Pali) region.

items.title: 3rd Stage of Metallic Money — Metal Pieces (Coin-like)
items.period: c. 5000–1000 BCE (as stated on board header)
notes: Circular coin-like metal pieces, sometimes with engraved/raised symbols.

items.title: 3rd Stage of Metallic Money — Stone Pieces (Coin-like)
items.period: c. 5000–1000 BCE (as stated on board header)
notes: Circular stone pieces also bear similar engraved/raised symbols.

items.title: Decorative Metal Pieces Used as Money
materials: Bronze and silver mix (beads, small ornaments)
notes: Small designer beads from bronze with silver mix used both as jewellery and as money.

items.title: Terracotta Coins with Ujjain Symbol
notes: Board explicitly mentions Ujjain symbol on these terracotta coins.

items.title: Ancient Decorative Bone Beads Used for Exchange
notes: Row of multi-coloured bone beads identified as being used for exchange.

items.title: Gold-Plated Ornaments (Lead/Mix core) used for Trade
items.period: Broadly dated boards; top mentions 2000–200 BCE and context of ‘Avanti Janapad’ (text partly blurred)
items.region: Central India (Avanti Janapad / Madhya Pradesh) & Kaushambi region referenced
notes: Ornamental ear/neck pieces indicated as both decoration and trade money.
Similar finds reported from Avanti Janapad and Kaushambi (Pali).

items.title: Mixed-Metal Metallic Rings (Necklace ‘beads/rings’)
notes: Used as necklace decoration; when required, used for trade.
Board states excavation from deep rivers; associated with Satavahana region.

items.title: Gold Plated Ornament (South India)
notes: Top-left card row shows a circular ornament piece; card labeled ‘Gold Plated Ornament — South India’.

items.title: Bronze Metal Tribal Arts (Usually used with holes)
notes: Small bronze figurative/abstract pieces meant to be strung/holed; used as money and adornment.

items.title: Gold Plated Ornaments (South India)
notes: Another card with ring-like piece; same label family as previous.

items.title: Lead Metal Human Shape — Saurashtra (Gujarat)
notes: Human-shaped lead token, card explicitly labels region.

items.title: Lead Metal Ornament Design — Saurashtra (Gujarat)
notes: Non-figurative ornament-shaped lead piece.

items.title: Lead Metal Fish Shape — Saurashtra (Gujarat)
notes: Fish-shaped lead token; explicitly labeled on card.

items.title: Bronze Metal Tribal Arts (Usually used with holes) — Set 2
notes: Lower-left card is another assortment of small bronze pieces.

items.title: Bend Bar Beads with Holes (Usually used with holes)
materials: Metal (likely bronze/lead mix; small bar forms)
notes: Card at bottom-right shows curved/bar beads with perforations.

items.title: Bronze Necklace ‘Snake’ (Usually used with holes)
notes: Single card shows a spiral ‘snake’ necklace element with a piercing to string; classified as primitive money.
